metadata.title: Micro(nano)plastics: A threat to human health?

sections.text:
Addresses Laboratoire Mer, Molécules, Santé (MMS, EA 2160), Université Catholique de l’Ouest, Angers F-49000 France
Corresponding author: Mouneyrac, Catherine (catherine.mouneyrac@ uco.fr)
Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health 2018, 1:17–23
This review comes from a themed issue on Micro and Nanoplastics
Edited by Dr. Teresa Rocha-Santos
For a complete overview see the Issue and the Editorial
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.coesh.2017.10.003
2468-5844/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords Microplastics, Nanoplastics, Additives, Food chain, Ingestion.
Introduction Today, plastic products can be found in several fields such as health, construction, and textiles. Global production of plastic has increased significantly, from 1.7 million tons in the 1950s to over 322 million tons in 2016 [1]. Plastic is made of synthetic organic polymers; the majority being polyethylene (PE, high and low density), polystyrene (PS), polypropylene (PP), polyvinyl chloride (PVC), polyurethane (PUR) and polyethylene terephthalate (PET). In addition, additives may be added to plastics to improve their characteristics such as strength, coloration or flame retardant properties. To understand MPs impacts, it is crucial to study their fate and their potential effects and their additives (e.g., Bisphenol A, phthalates, polybrominated diphenyl ethers, andmetals or metalloids) which for some of them can be classified as carcinogenic or endocrine disrupting.
www.sciencedirect.com
In recent years, the presence of plastic debris called microplastics (MPs), define as fragments smaller than 5 mm has been reported in diverse aquatic ecosystems [2e4]. Though the presence of nanoplastics (NPs) is difficult to ascertain, due to the inherent technical difficulties, recent studies shown that NPs are also being introduced in important quantities into the natural environment [5e7]. Since plastic items undergo continuous fragmentation, it is likely that MPs could become NPs and some studies suggested that the average size of sampled plastic particles seems to be decreasing [8].
Concerns about toxic impacts of MPs and eventually NPs for human health have been raised, but investigations are still sparse [9]. To compare the number of studies focusing on MPs/NPs effects towards human health or the environment, the number of articles found in Web of science using different keywords (“Microplastics human health”, “Microplastics environment”, Nanoplastics human health”, “nanoplastics environment”) was summarized in Fig. 1. Clearly, a much higher number of studies are available on MPs in the environment compared to human exposure (articles published from 2006 to 2017). The aim of this review is to present an overview of the different exposure routes for humans and potential effects of MPs and NPs, including their additives, from commercial items and discarded debris through the food chain. Since to date reports on human health is very sparse, we used previous work from environmental studies on MPs, and engineered nanoparticles for NPs to try to predict potential translocation and eventually effect on humans.
Routes of human exposure Oral Drinking water The presence of MPs in soil and freshwater ecosystems has been measured, including in locations used as sources of drinking water representing a way of MPs human exposure, particularly if plastic particles can pass through the filtration systems of wastewater treatment [10,11]. It has been estimated that daily discharges could ranged from w50,000 up to nearly 15 million particles [12].
Food chain: marine products Aquatic organisms may be contaminated by MPs (and NPs), either through loaded water or the feeding from other organisms and may serve as a source of human exposure. Concerning bivalves, humans consume the whole soft tissues which may contain microscopic plastic
Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health 2018, 1:17–23
debris. In addition, fish may be contaminated after fishing during their storage and transportation in plastic containers of friable polystyrene.
Plastic particles have been detected in various organisms from the lowest levels of food chain such as zooplanktonic organisms [13,14] to the highest levels in both invertebrates (Crustacea, mollusks) and vertebrates (fish) [15,16]. Along the Mediterranean coast of Turkey, 1822 MP particles were extracted from stomachs and intestines of 1337 fish specimen with the majority of ingested particles represented by fibers (70%) and hard plastics (20.8%) [16]. In different species of fish from coastal (21) and freshwater (6) of China, MPs were abundant in 26 species, accounting for 55.9e92.3% of the total number of plastics items in each species [17]. For benthopelagic fish, MPs were higher in sea fish than freshwater organisms. In Norwegian coast, lower level of plastics (including MPs) was measured in the Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) fish with 3% of plastic found in the stomachs examined [18]. Low quantities of MPs were found in bivalves from German (0.36 0.07 particles/g) and French/Belgian/Dutch farms (0.2 0.3 particles/g) [15,19]. In Canada, 500 times greater quantities of MPs were measured in the same bivalve, suggesting different levels of contamination between sites or differences between MPs extraction methods [20].
Translocation of MPs across the gastrointestinal tract has been demonstrated in the laboratory for crabs and mussels [21,22]. The presence of MPs/NPs in tissues beyond the gastrointestinal tract has yet to be evaluated in fish [23]. However, a study reported the presence of MPs in the livers of fish fed plastic particles [24].
Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health 2018, 1:17–23
Other food items Humans may also be directly exposed to MPs and NPs through the actual ingestion of these particles from, honey [25] and beers [26]. After the examination of 24 German beer brands, authors measured from 2 to 79 fibers L 1 and from 12 to 109 fragments L 1 in samples. Recently, MP-like particles, predominantly fragments of PP and PE larger than 149 mm were measured out of 17 salt brands from 8 countries [27]. Even so, authors concluded a negligible health risks associated with the consumption of these salts, MPs can still reach the human organism through other type of food such as fish and bivalves [28].
MPs can also be ingested indirectly through personal care products (toothpaste, scrubs).
Dermal exposure: water and cosmetics Dermal contact may occur when humans interact with water contaminated with MPs/NPs during washing or through facial/body scrubs also containing MPs/NPs [5]. But, due to the size of MPs and since uptake of particles across skin requires penetration of striatum corneum which is limited to particles below 100 nm, absorption through the skin is unlikely to occur. However, NPs could eventually penetrate into/through human skin [29].
Inhalation: air Human exposure to MPs/NPs through inhalation could occur after MPs/NPs become airborne, potentially from wave action in aquatic environments or the application of wastewater treatment sludge. Furthermore, MPs have been detected in atmospheric fallout suggesting another
www.sciencedirect.com
possible source of inhalation exposure. While very few studies can be found on MPs presence in the air compared to aquatic environments, several reports suggest that MPs are present in the atmosphere. As an example, MPs (fibers), were detected (29e280 particles/m2/day) on an urban rooftop as a consequence of atmospheric fallout [30]. If some MPs are able to pass through wastewater treatment plants [31], then a portion of the plastic particles will be able to be retained in the sewage sludge. If such contaminated sludge is applied to land, for agricultural purposes, MPs could be found in terrestrial environments [32]. No information was readily available assessing the occurrence of NPs in the atmosphere whereas presence of NPs in the atmosphere is well documented [33].
Impact of micro-nanoplastics on human health Effect of microplastic Uptake: translocation across the gut The translocation of MPs across the gastrointestinal tract has been for few terrestrial and marine organisms [21,34] but fewer reports are available on mammals [35,36]. Translocation across the mammalian gut into the lymphatic system of various types and sizes of microparticles (between 0.1 and 150 mm) has been demonstrated in studies involving humans (0.2 and 150 mm) [35]. In dogs, PVC (5e110 mm) appeared in the portal vein, which will then reach the liver [37]. Small intestinal uptake in rodents was shown after using 2 mm latex particles (0.04e0.3%) [38]. In a study conducted in vitro, limited absorption (0.2%) of polylactide-co-glycolide microparticles (3 mm) was measured in human mucosal colon tissue. The mucosal colon tissue of patients with inflammatory bowel disease, showed increased transport (0.45% as compared to 0.2% in healthy controls) in relation to greater gut permeability [36].
Few studies investigated the potential mechanism of uptake of MPs. Because of their small size, phagocytosis or endocytosis could be the preferential route of uptake for MPs. Phagocytosis by macrophages in the intestinal epithelium may occur with particles >0.5 mm [39] and endothelial cells may also internalize larger particles of 5 mm by endocytosis [40]. No information can be found on the biodistribution of microparticles [39].
Potential toxicity The physical presence of MPs may be toxic due to their inherent ability to induce intestinal blockage or tissue abrasion [34,41]. In earthworms (Eisenia andrei), fibrosis, congestion and inflammatory infiltrates were observed after exposure to MPs (from 62 to 1000 mg/ kg of PE) [34]. In sea bass (Dicentrarchus labrax), moderate to severe histopathological alterations of the intestine were measured, after 30e90 days of exposure
www.sciencedirect.com
to PVC MP through ingestion [41]. According to the authors, damages recorded after 90 days of exposure could be responsible for totally compromising intestinal functions.
To date, one in vitro study can be found on toxicity of MPs towards human health. The authors measured oxidative stress through reactive oxygen species generation in cerebral and epithelial human cells after exposure to PS MPs (10 mm) and PS NPs (40 and 250 nm) at 10 mg/L [42]. Recently, tissue distribution, accumulation, and tissue-specific health risk of PS MPs was studied in mice [43]. Results indicated that ingestion of MPs (0,5 mg/day of PS of 5, and 20 mm) lead to accumulation of particles in liver, kidney and gut. Thus, tissue-accumulation kinetics and distribution pattern was related to the MPs particle size. In addition, analyses in mice liver of biochemical biomarkers and metabolomic profiles suggested that MPs exposure induced alteration of oxidative stress, energy and lipid metabolism, but also neurotoxic effect. Those results raise concern of cellular toxicity towards human liver cells. MPs present in the lumen may interact with the fluid through adsorptive reactions facilitated by their large-area surfaces and charge. Large proteins could be adsorbed to the surface of plastic particles which could lead to the alteration of the immune system of the gut and local inflammation could occur [44]. This could further induce the uptake of MPs by the gut [45].
Effect of nanoplastic: extrapolation from engineered nanomaterials? Potential uptake: translocation across the gut A special concern of NP particles is their ability to penetrate cells and the gut epithelium. Oral uptake of PS nanoparticles has been studied for some decades, and gastrointestinal translocation (both in vivo and in vitro) of engineered nanoparticles (Titanium dioxide, Zinc oxide, Silver) has been explored [46]. After translocation across the gut barrier, nanoparticles can reach the circulation, depending on their size and surface charge. NPs have been studied in rodent in vivo and human in vitro studies and the oral bioavailability of PS nanoparticles (50 nm) was estimated to vary between 0.2 and 2% [47].
So far, no studies has permitted to establish a link between size, composition and uptake of NPs. Different uptakes of PS particles (50e500 nm) have been measured in various in vitro intestinal models ranging from 1.5 to 10%, with various NPs size, surface chemistry and in vitro model [48]. Interestingly, it has been reported that oral in vivo exposure to 50 nm PS particles resulted in increased iron uptake, suggesting that exposure to NPs affects the barrier properties of the gut epithelium [49].
Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health 2018, 1:17–23
Potential toxicity Very little information can be found on the potential toxicity of NPs towards humans. Studies on the potential risks of engineered nanoparticles are available, but the extrapolation to NPs toxicity is very delicate. Metal oxide nanoparticles are most widely studied, but effects can be due to the nanoparticle or to the released ions. In addition, toxicity can be related to the volume/surface ratio of the nanoparticles which will alter their reactivity. Since NPs are inert material, the fate of inert nanoparticles such as gold (Au) could be a starting point to study the toxicity of NPs. Previous work measured the uptake of Au nanoparticles in liver and spleen macrophages in vivo, and showed an induction of acute inflammation and apoptosis in the liver [50]. These effects appeared to be size-dependent and supported by differential gene expression in relation to detoxification, lipid metabolism and defense responses. NPs have different physicochemical properties compared to nanoparticles which might induce specific effects [51]. While studies with these particular metal nanoparticles could provide valuable hints on toxicity on NPs, novel nanoparticle systems need to be considered for future studies assessing the potential toxicity of NPs.
Indirect effects of MPs Leaching of additives Plastic polymers are generally considered inert and of low concern to human health. Usually, health risks relating to their use are attributed to the presence of the wide range of plastic additives they may contain [52]. In addition, metal-based catalysts used during the production of water bottles could be released into the drinking water. Release of antimony (Sb) used as catalyst in commercially PET plastic bottles has been shown under high temperatures (60e85 C) [53]. Since Sb may cause health effects (nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea), these types of plastic bottles and their storage at elevated temperature promoting deterioration of water quality should be avoided. In another study Zn accumulation in the earthworm Lumbricus terrestris exposed to PE fragments associated with Zn was shown and Zn desorption in synthetic earthworm guts was higher from these MPs (40e60%) than soil (2e15%) [54].
The potential migration of polymer constituents and additives into food and drinks is then considered a major route of exposure of the human population. While the possible role of MPs in transferring contaminants (e.g., phthalates) between species has been raised [55], other contaminated sources (e.g., water, sediment, food) may be of equal or greater importance than plastics for chemical transfer in aquatic organisms [56].
Adsorption of contaminants and vector of pathogens Due to their high surface area to volume ratio and hydrophobicity, MPs and NPs may serve as a vector for
Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health 2018, 1:17–23
exposure to environmental contaminants. This transfer of chemicals into organisms at lower trophic levels, raises the possibility that such chemicals may biomagnify in predators, including humans [57]. Oliviera et al. (2013) exposed juveniles of fish (Pomatoschistus microps) to PE microspheres (MS) (0, 18.4 and 184 mg/ L), in the presence of pyrene (20 and 200 mg/L) for 96 h [58]. Results shown that PE MPs modulate the bioavailability or biotransformation of pyrene and simultaneous exposure to PEMPs and pyrene decreased the energy available through the aerobic pathway of energy production. In the crustacean Daphnia magna, NPs (50 nm) co-exposed with phenanthrene showed an additive effect with higher immobilization of organisms compared to the exposure of compounds alone [59]. In another study conducted in lobster (Nephrops norvegicus) the presence of chemicals adsorbed on ingested PE MS did not lead to significant bioaccumulation of PCBs in Ref. [60]. There was a limited uptake of PCBs in Nephrops tail tissue after ingestion of PCB-loaded PE MS, while almost no PCBs were detected in animals exposed to PS MPs. On the contrary, In mussels Mytilus galloprovincialis, great capability of pyrene-contaminated PEMPs to transfer pyrene in digestive glands was shown [24]. Cellular effects were also measured including alterations of immunological responses, lysosomal compartment, peroxisomal proliferation, antioxidant system, neurotoxic effects, genotoxicity and changes in gene expression profile.
Additionally, microbial colonization of MPs may occur and be regarded as vectors for exposure to potential pathogens [61]. In North/Baltic Sea, potentially pathogenic Vibrio parahaemolyticus identified on a number of MP particles, such as PE, PP, and PS was discovered [62].
Conclusion and recommendations Adverse effects from MPs/NPs may result from a combination of the plastic’s intrinsic toxicity (e.g., physical damage); chemical composition (leaching of additives); and ability to adsorb, concentrate, and release environmental pollutants into the organisms [23,63]. MPs could also serve as a vector for pathogens, leading to potentially dispersion of species in a new ecosystem [64]. SinceMPs have been detected in various trophic levels, additional studies need to be conducted to evaluate the bioaccumulation of adsorbed contaminants and eventually biomagnification. This may occur in higher trophic levels, and could eventually affect human health [23].

The article discusses the physical and chemical properties of MPs that are potentially relevant to their ecotoxicity, including particle size, particle shape, crystallinity, surface chemistry, and polymer and additive composition. This is the first article to address the need for a structured approach to the testing of different properties to identify which are the most relevant drivers of microplastic toxicity.

This article presents toxicity of MPs and NPs with phenanthrene to Daphnia magna and effects of MPs and NPs on the environmental fate and bioaccumulation of 14C-phenanthrene in fresh water. This is the first study to provide comprehensive information on the impact of MPs and NPs on the toxicity, bioaccumulation, and degradation of a model PAH compound Phe in fresh water system with a model test organism D. magna.

Concerns about toxic impacts of MPs and eventually NPs for human health have been raised, but investigations are still sparse [9].

metadata.abstractText: The presence and effects of plastic debris is increasingly investigated. The majority of studies focuses on microplastics (MPs), but few reports suggest that plastic fragments in the <100 nm size range, referred to as nanoplastics (NPs), may also be formed in the aquatic environment and further to humans. This paper provides a review on routes of human exposure and potential effects of MPs and NPs to human health. MPs/NPs could potentially induce: physical damages through particles itself, and biological stress through MPs/NPs alone or leaching of additives (inorganic and organic). Future research should evaluate trophic transfer of MPs/NPs with their associated chemicals through the marine food web. Addresses Laboratoire Mer, Molécules, Santé (MMS, EA 2160), Université Catholique de l’Ouest, Angers F-49000 France Corresponding author: Mouneyrac, Catherine (catherine.mouneyrac@ uco.fr) Current Opinion in Environmental Science & Health 2018, 1:17–23 This review comes from a themed issue on Micro and Nanoplastics Edited by Dr. Teresa Rocha-Santos For a complete overview see the Issue and the Editorial https://doi.org/10.1016/j.coesh.2017.10.003 2468-5844/© 2017 Elsevier B.V.
